feed.title: SAP Community - SAP Concur

entry.title: SAP Integration with Concur Solutions: Budget checks/reservations for Public Sector customers
entry.content:
Budget checks and reservations for Public Sector customers are available as part of SAP Integration with Concur Solutions, a.k.a. ICS or Native Integration. A colleague of mine announced the availability of the functionality a while ago with the following blog post: Enable cost and budget control through our new integration between SAP Concur and SAP S/4 HANA. In this blog post, I want to explain what is available in the systems with focus on the budget checking/reservation aspects.

The functionality is available for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, S/4HANA 2022 and S/4HANA 2023 in combination with Concur Professional Edition. Public Sector Management (PSM) functionality needs to be active in the Financials system.

 

Scenarios

For checking or reserving budgets, ICS distinguishes 3 scenarios:

Overview: Scenarios

  1. Budget checks/reservations based on a travel request (TR). The reserved budget is consumed/replaced later by the actuals posting of one or more expense reports (ERs) which reference the TR.
  2. Budget checks/reservations based on an ER. The reserved budget is consumed/replaced later by the actuals posting of the ER.
    Note: The technical vehicle for this check is the document type expense report obligation (ERO) from Concur's Financial Integration Services (FIS) API.
  3. Budget checks/reservations based on a TR, followed up by budget checks/reservations based on an ER which consume/replace the reservation done by the TR, followed up by the actuals posting of the ER.

Concur Configuration

ICS retrieves transactional data from Concur through the FIS API. For budget checks and reservations, 2 new document types have been made available in FIS: Travel Request and Expense Report Obligation. Whether these document types are created or not, depends on several things:

  • Enablement of Funds & Grants Integration on Expense Group level in addition to the enablement of the Financial Integration itself
  • Dedicated steps in the workflow of a TR and/or an ER to trigger the budget check/reservation.

You define in the workflow of a TR and/or an ER

  • when an interaction with the Financials systems should take place, e.g., after submitting the TR but before approval, and,
  • what type of interaction should happen, i.e. a check or a reservation.

Example: TR workflow

 

Interaction means that a document will be put into the FIS queue and that the document needs to be processed by a consumer, e.g., ICS, for the workflow of a TR or an ER to continue.

Note: You can add several check and reservation steps to a workflow if needed.

A third type of interaction is automatically triggered although not visible in the workflow definition. Concur will request to release any reserved, but not consumed budget for a TR or an ER if the budget reservation is no longer required, e.g., if a TR is closed.

Within Concur you can also define how Concur should react on errors that are raised by the Financials system. That piece of configuration is part of the Integration Manager role and visible under Administration -> Company -> Tools. In addition, there is also a monitoring application:

Funds & Grants Configuration and Monitoring within Tools section

Funds & Grants: Integration Configuration

Funds & Grants: Integration Monitor

 

Financials / ICS Configuration

Pre-requisite: PSM functionality is active in your Financials system.

If you want ICS to handle TRs and/or EROs, you need to select the corresponding option from Integration Activities within the Concur Integration Setup app:ICS: Select which Budget Integration option you want to use

After you have selected a Budget Integration option, a wizard will become accessible to define configuration details. The wizard is similar to the one available for the actuals posting of an ER (Financial Posting -> Create/Change Expense Report Import). In fact, some configuration settings are inherited from that configuration and can't be changed.

Travel Request Import: Filter Definition

ICS doesn't support the replication of the PSM-specific master data objects so far. When building the integration, we've assumed that the PSM-specific objects will be derived in many cases in the Financials system, e.g., through the PSM derivation logic (transaction FMDERIVE). But if a PSM-specific master data object is entered on the TR or ER, that object can be included for budget checks/reservations and the actuals posting of an ER.

Configuration: Activate Cost Objects for Public Sector Management

Example

Now, let's have a look at the system interactions for the following Funds & Grants scenario:

Example Process Flow for Funds & Grants

 Starting point for the system interactions is the submission of a TR:

TR with 2 entries

A TR document is put into the FIS queue for requesting a funds check from the Financials system:

TR Funds Check

The TR document is retrieved and processed by ICS. The result of the processing is returned to Concur. In the example, sufficient budget is available and this information is sent back to Concur. The audit trail of the TR is updated with the information. The TR workflow continues with the approval step. After the TR is approved, a budget reservation should happen. A TR document is put into the FIS queue to request the budget reservation. In the given example, a total of $300 is reserved for 2 different travel request entries. The budget consumption type is 52 (Travel Request Pre-encumbrances). In general, an own reservation is made per entry respectively allocation in case of allocation split.
Note: The previously visible funds check is removed from the display within ICS' Concur Documents as the funds check is no longer relevant.

Travel Request: Funds Reservation

 

Budget reservation in PSM

 

As the funds reservation was successful, the TR is now approved and can be linked to an ER. As usual, the initial cost estimations of the TR didn't match reality. One expense of the trip is higher than expected, the other expense is lower than expected.

ER with 2 expenses

After submitting the ER, a document is put into the FIS queue requesting a budget reservation for the ER.

Expense Report Obligation in Concur Documents monitor

The successful budget reservation leads to several updates:

  • Concur is updated with the result of the processing in Financials, i.e., the successful budget reservation. The expense report is moved to the approval step.
  • A budget reservation is created for the expense report with consumption type 53 (Expense Report Obligation). Please ignore the description for the consumption type on the screenshot below.

Note: If there are expenses in the ER that aren't linked to a TR entry, then additional budget will be reserved for those expenses without consuming from the TR budget.

Budget Reservation for an ER, consumption type 53

One more update happened: The Expense Report Obligation (ERO) consumes budget that has previously been reserved for the TR. If you look at the TR budget data, you will notice a change. How this update looks depends on PSM settings. In my set up, the TR data only shows the consumed budget. In other set ups, you might even see that the ERO required more than the initially reserved budget for one of the expenses.

Updated TR budget data

After the ER is approved. The actuals posting of the ER happens. Thereby consuming the budget reservation for the ERO. As the posting was successful, the ER on Concur side is updated and moved to the next workflow step. The journal entry numbers are visible in the ER's audit trail.

Expense Report in Concur Documents monitor

A journal entry has been created for the ER

Journal entry line: Details for an expense G/L account line

The budget reservation for the ER has been consumed by the successful actuals posting. This is reflected when you look up the budget reservation for the ER.

Expense Report Obligation: Update after successful ER posting

Depending on the set up for the ER, a request to release any remaining budget reservation will be triggered after the successful posting of the ER or after the payment notification happened. As all of the  budget has been consumed by the actuals posting, there's no update within PSM. Only an additional expense report obligation document will become visible in the Concur Documents monitor which is similar to what I will show below for the TR.

As the trip is now complete, the TR can be closed which leads to another update in Financials. A document of type Travel Request is put into the FIS queue requesting the release of all remaining budget reservations for the TR. In the given example, this means that a reservation of $50 needs to be released.

Closing the TR triggers a request to release any remaining budget reservation

Release TR budget

If you've got questions/feedback, please leave a comment.

entry.title: AI Innovation Starts Here: Join the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative Today
entry.content:
Ready to harness the power of AI and transform your industry? With SAP’s advanced AI technology, we help you optimize operations, enhance decision-making, and drive efficiency across your business.

Now’s your chance to influence the next wave of AI innovation. Join our SAP Customer Engagement Initiative projects, where your feedback will directly shape the AI solutions we develop to meet your unique needs. Your insights will be instrumental in creating tools that help you achieve real, measurable success.

Don’t miss this opportunity to lead the way in digital transformation with AI. Register for the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative today – registration closes on March 28, 2025!

  • BTP AI based Data Anonymization Service
  • Create AI-driven extensions and automations with SAP Build
  • Improving the Admin's and Solution Architect's Experience on SAP BTP
  • Insights into Business processes with Business Event Logging
  • Joule and GenAI use cases in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud
  • OData UI Service from scratch Generator
  • Research into AI-Assisted User Learning Rollout for Adoption
  • Sales and Use Tax Reporting in United States - User Research
  • SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Provisioning, Integration with Joule 
  • SAP Concur - AI Managed Expense Reports
  • SAP CX AI Toolkit
  • SAP Integration Suite
  • The AI-Driven Future of New Product Introduction (NPI)

We believe that collaboration is key to unlocking innovation. By joining forces with our customers and partners, we can collectively shape the future of SAP’s products and change the way businesses operate using AI.

Seize this opportunity – register on influence.sap.com and be a part of the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative Cycle 1 in 2025! If you are also interested in other SAP Customer Engagement Initiative projects that are currently open for registration, check out the full list here.

Warm regards, 
Your SAP Customer Engagement Initiative Team 

Follow-up after registration: When you register for a project, you will be invited to an introductory call with the SAP project lead. At this point further participation is optional. Typically, all activities are governed by the Feedback Agreement with SAP.

entry.title: Subscribing to SAP Concur’s Event Subscription Service
entry.content:
I have been a Technical Consultant at SAP Concur for quite some time and have worked with many clients to help them build their interfaces between their systems and SAP Concur. While SAP Concur offers many APIs that can be called by external applications, there are also use cases where clients need their application to act based upon a trigger in Concur. The event subscription service can help in such cases by allowing external applications to subscribe to specific events and receive real-time notifications. In this blog post, we will explore how you can subscribe your applications to start receiving events.

 

Prerequisites Concur

To use SAP Concur's web service APIs, you must ensure that this is part of your contract with SAP Concur.

This post will not discuss authentication with Concur Expense.  Please see this post to get an explanation creating an application in Concur.

You will need an application with the following SCOPEs:

  • events.topic.read
  • dependent on the event(s) you wish to subscribe to, further scopes are needed (check documentation)

 

Prerequisites Application Endpoint (webhook)

Your application needs to have a public facing endpoint available where the Event Subscription Service can deliver (POST) events to. The endpoint should:

  • be set up to handle the number of events (implementing a queue is recommended)
  • ensure reasonable uptime
  • server endpoint must be accessible with a certificate that is signed by a known Certificate Authority and reachable through DNS

It is strongly recommended that you use the certificate Common Name as the authentication mechanism to ensure your endpoint is accessed by Concur’s service.

 

Introduction

At the moment of publishing there are events available for:

  • Expense workflow
  • Request workflow
  • Financial Integration
  • Itinerary
  • User Provisioning
  • Identity change
  • Document Tax Compliance
  • Travel

To start receiving events you must register your system with the Event Subscription Service and specify the topic you’re subscribing to (some topics even allow for additional filtering).

Detailed Walkthrough

  1. Obtain application-level Bearer token
  2. Get available event topics
  3. Check existing subscriptions
  4. Create/update a subscription
  5. Verify subscription
  6. Delete subscription
  7. Activate subscription

Before we dive into the details, I would like to highlight the resources where SAP Concur has these APIs documented. On the Concur Developer Center you will find a section on the Event Subscription Service v4. It is also listed on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub under Event Service.

I would also recommend checking out the Postman collection that I prepared. It will include all the steps that are described in this blogpost.

 

Obtain application-level Bearer token

The Event Subscription Services (ESS) v4 APIs require an application-level bearer token, which can be retrieved by using the client credentials grant type. Use below CURL statement to create the API call and replace the dataCenterURI, clientId and clientSecret.

 

curl --location ' https://{{dataCenterURI}}/oauth2/v0/token' \
--header 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
--data-urlencode 'client_id={{clientId}}' \
--data-urlencode 'client_secret={{clientSecret}}' \
--data-urlencode 'grant_type=client_credentials'

 

Note: you can find what data center URI to use here.

 

Get available event topics

What event topics you can subscribe to will depend on the scopes that are available on the registered application. In the documentation (SAP Concur Developer Center | Event Subscription Management) you will find the necessary scopes required for the different event.

To find out what topics your application can register, you can retrieve the available topics for your application.

Example API call

 

GET /events/v4/topics

 

 

Check existing subscriptions

You can check whether your application already subscribed to any events. The following call would return all subscriptions for your application.

Example API call

 

GET /events/v4/subscriptions

 

 Example API response:

 

Create/update a subscription

If you would like to create a new subscription, then you will need to register a (descriptive) system identifier (id) for a specific event topic (topic) for a particular webhook endpoint (endpoint). Each subscription is linked to one topic and each application can have up to 5 subscriptions.

Some event topics allow for additional filtering. Check the documentation if that is the case for the even that you wish to describe to. In the example below the filter is set to subscribe to all types of events within the topic.

Example API call

 

PUT /events/v4/subscriptions/webhook 
{  
   "id": "external-approval-system-xyz",  
   "filter": ".*",  
   "topic": "public.concur.expense.report",  
   "webHookConfig": {    
      "endpoint": "https://some.valid.webhook.endpoint/"  
   }
}

 

A successful response would be a 200 message with a message stating the subscription was saved successfully.

 

Verify subscription

To verify your subscription, you can do another GET call with the “id” from the registration in the endpoint. Taking the id from the previous example (“external-approval-system-xyz”) this would look like the example below.

Example API call

 

GET /events/v4/subscriptions/external-approval-system-xyz

 

Example API response:

 

Delete subscription

Subscriptions that are no longer needed can be deleted.

Example API call

 

DELETE /events/v4/subscriptions/external-approval-system-xyz

 

 

Activate subscription

By this point you’ve probably used the previous subscription APIs to register one or more endpoints for one or more types of events. The subscription itself will not activate the Event Subscription Service for your application. The final step is to (re-)create a company JWT, which will update the ESS subscriptions with the company Id of the Concur entity.

In your Concur system, navigate to Administration > Authentication Admin > Company Request Token

Enter your client id as the App ID and submit to generate a request token. Afterwards follow the steps described on the same page to complete the process of obtaining a Company JWT. Please see this post to get a detailed explanation on authentication within Concur. 

Once done, please verify again your subscription by doing a GET and you should see that the “companyIds” array is no longer empty and instead populated with the company id of your Concur entity.

 

Event Subscription Service behavior

The service has the following characteristics from the subscriber perspective:

  • Requests will come from us.api.concursolutions.com, emea.api.concursolutions.com, or cn.api.concursolutions.com.
  • Connection will always be established using a mutual TLS with webhook.api.concursolutions.com x509 certificate.
  • Requests will always have a digital signature.
  • Requests will be re-tried when the subscriber responds with HTTP Response Code(s): 5xx, 401, 403, or 429.
  • Requests will not be re-tried when subscriber responds with HTTP Response Code(s):
    • 2xx – Indicates successful receipt of the event.
    • 4xx – Indicates posted event is unexpected or incorrectly formatted.
  • Request will be retried until delivery OR event retention period expiration.
  • Event retention period is 72 hours from the time of event being published.
  • Events are not archived, but all of the event delivery attempts/responses are logged and retained for 30 days.

 

Conclusion

The Event Subscription Service will be very useful if you are building an application that needs to act upon a trigger/change that occurs in your Concur system. Such triggers could for example be a certain step in the workflow, a change on the user profile, a travel itinerary change, etc. While these subscriptions may sometimes trigger more events than your application may need, it will include enough information to identify what events to act upon.

Events allow applications to respond to specific scenarios immediately. They do not need to schedule API calls to find and identify the scenario on which it needs to act.

With the examples shown in this blogpost and the linked Postman collection, you should be well on your way to register and activate your first event subscription.

 

Share and Connect

What do you think?  Do you have anything to add? Leave a comment below.

Did you find it useful? Give us a like and share on social media.

Do you have questions or want to know more about SAP Concur and its offerings? Please follow us here.

Thank you!

entry.title: Do you know how to use Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT) in Concur Expense Professional Edition?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Working with Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT) in Concur Expense Professional Edition learning journey.

Overview
This learning journey helps you gain a solid understanding of using Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT) in Concur Expense Professional Edition.

Learning objectives
At the end of this learning journey, administrators and consultants will be able to, in Concur Expense Professional Edition:

  • Describe FBT and why tracking it is essential to your business
  • Explain to your users how to complete an expense report that contains FBT-related expenses
  • Identify the considerations for users when they are subject to FBT
  • Compare Attendee Status and Attendee Types
  • Configure the Attendee Types to support FBT
  • Configure FBT in the Tax Administration tool
  • Configure the Attendee Detail View to support FBT
  • Activate FBT on your Australia Policy
  • Activate the Travel Diary on your Australia Policy
  • Explain how FBT affects SAE

Prerequisites
Learners should have a firm understanding of how Concur Expense operates as a business user.
Please complete the Getting Started with Concur Expense for Business Users learning journey before completing this course.

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! We are here to support you. 

I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Are you ready to use Concur Expense Mobile on Android?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Getting Started with Concur Expense Mobile Android for Users learning journey.
With the completion of this learning journey, you will be prepared for the certification C_S4CS. 

Learning Objectives
This learning journey with demos and practice simulations will introduce business users to the basics of Concur Expense (Mobile Android) such as profile features, creating a new expense report, the expense report approval process and roles, as well as additional expense report features needed to be successful in submitting their expense reports.

Learning objectives

  • Explain an overview of SAP Concur and how to do basic tasks (signing in, profile, home page).
  • Set Up Your Concur Expense Profile.
  • Create a New Expense Report and basic expense line items.
  • Explain What Happens Once You Submit your Expense Report.
  • Set up Additional Expense Report Features.

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 

Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! We are here to support you. 

I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Preparation for setting up integration between ECC or S/4HANA OnPrem and Concur
entry.content:
The standard SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (SAP ICS) makes it really easy to quickly setup and configure an integration between your ECC or S/4HANA OnPrem system and SAP Concur. Our Concur Service Delivery team have helped many clients in getting this setup, but there are certain issues we often see clients run into. Fortunately, there are a few easy checks and guidelines you can follow to avoid them.

The purpose of this article is to give a quick and simple overview of the guidelines to ensure you are best prepared for a smooth integration. 

Add-ons:

For on-premise integration, it is essential that the latest service packs (SAP Note 2298170) are installed. You can find these in the Master Guide on the SAP Help Portal.

The following add-ons must be downloaded and installed for SAP ECC and SAP S/4 HANA On-Prem 1511-1909:

  • CTE_FND 100 – Foundation Component (always required)
  • CTE_HCM 100 – HCM Integration (optional, for the replication of employee master data and payroll / Payroll)
  • CTE_FIN 100 – Financial Integration (required for FI postings and the replication of cost object types)

Installation instructions for installing the add-ons using SAINT can be found in SAP Note 2298170 under sections 3 and 4.
Other add-ons should not be installed, only the ones listed above are required.
Assign authorizations and AuthProfiles according to the MasterGuide.

Importing Certificates:

Unlock the firewall and import the certificates in STRUST under SSL Client Standard.

  • DigiCert Global Root CA
  • DigiCert Global Root G2
  • DigiCert Global Root G3

The certificates can be obtained from the DigiCert website:
www.digicert.com/digicert-root-certificates.htm

Enable Communication (Firewall):

The following addresses must be allowed in the firewall for outbound communication via REST API:

EMEA datacenter

  • eu2.concursolutions.com
  • eu2.api.concursolutions.com

US datacenter

  • us2.concursolutions.com
  • us2.api.concursolutions.com

Detailed information on this, as well as on integration via middleware (if necessary), can be found in SAP Note 2914977 - FAQ: Concur Certificates, Authentication, and Connectivity.

For customers with SAP integration platforms, we recommend the following documentation in the SAP Business Accelerator:  https://api.sap.com/package/ConcurIntegrationDataExportandFIPosting/integrationflow

Next Steps:

  • Review the settings of the Crypto Library and Cipher Suite (SAP Note  2914977)

entry.title: Preparations for setting up integration between S/4HANA Private Cloud and Concur
entry.content:
The standard SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (SAP ICS) makes it really easy to quickly setup and configure an integration between your S/4HANA Private Cloud system and SAP Concur. Our Concur Service Delivery team have helped many clients in getting this setup, but there are certain issues we often see clients run into. Fortunately, there are a few easy checks and guidelines you can follow to avoid them.

The purpose of this article is to give a quick and simple overview of the guidelines to ensure you are best prepared for a smooth integration. 

Integration:

 For integration with S/4HANA Private Cloud version 2020 and higher, it is crucial that you select the documentation on the SAP Help Portal according to the version you are using (see screenshot below).

Starting from SAP S/4HANA 2020, your system will automatically receive the latest software version, as the integration function is delivered as a core feature and no longer as an add-on.

Authorizations and AuthProfiles should be assigned according to the Master Guide (again make sure you’ve selected your version).

Further information about your version can be found in SAP Note 2976103 .

Importing Certificates:

Unlock the firewall and import the certificates in STRUST under SSL Client Standard.

  • DigiCert Global Root CA
  • DigiCert Global Root G2
  • DigiCert Global Root G3

The certificates can be obtained from the DigiCert website:
www.digicert.com/digicert-root-certificates.htm

Enable Communication (Firewall):

The following addresses must be allowed in the firewall for outbound communication via REST API:

EMEA datacenter

  • eu2.concursolutions.com
  • eu2.api.concursolutions.com

US datacenter

  • us2.concursolutions.com
  • us2.api.concursolutions.com

Detailed information on this, as well as on integration via middleware (if required), can be found in SAP Note 2914977 - FAQ: Concur Certificates, Authentication, and Connectivity.

For customers with SAP integration platforms, we recommend the following documentation in the SAP Business Accelerator:  https://api.sap.com/package/ConcurIntegrationDataExportandFIPosting/integrationflow

Next Steps:

  • Review the settings of the Crypto Library and Cipher Suite (SAP Note  2914977)

entry.title: Preparations for setting up integration between S/4HANA Public Cloud and Concur
entry.content:
The standard SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (SAP ICS) makes it really easy to quickly setup and configure an integration between your S/4HANA Public Cloud system and SAP Concur. Our Concur Service Delivery team have helped many clients in getting this setup, but there are certain issues we often see clients run into. For S/4HANA Public Cloud the integration is available by default, but there are still a few things you can check upfront. 

The purpose of this article is to give a quick and simple overview of the guidelines to ensure you are best prepared for a smooth integration. 

Integration:

Your system will automatically receive the latest software version, as the integration function is delivered as a core feature and no longer as an add-on.

Authorizations and AuthProfiles should be assigned according to the Master Guide.

For SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud systems, SAP Concur is available as a standardized catalog integration, without the need for additional add-on installation. It will be automatically updated along with your cloud system.

Next Steps:

As a basis for activation and information on what is automatically carried out in the background, we recommend the following webseite, which describes the integration and all related processes for cloud systems.

The aforementioned website is also linked on the main SAP Help page for S/4HANA Cloud.:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD_INTEGRATION_WITH_CONCUR_SOLUTIONS

entry.title: The Rise of Intelligent Tax: How AI is Transforming Tax Operations and Compliance
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) has moved beyond the realm of science fiction and is now actively shaping our everyday lives. Whether it’s recommending what we buy online, helping self-driving cars avoid traffic, or identifying fraud in banking, AI is making industries work faster, smarter, and more efficiently. At its foundation, AI allows machines to analyze data, learn from it, and make decisions. AI is automating tasks that previously relied heavily on human effort.

Even the complex and cautious world of taxation is undergoing a digital transformation, thanks to AI. Tax functions within organizations have traditionally faced challenges like overwhelming regulations, repetitive processes, and frequent legislative updates. Today, AI is helping these teams simplify workflows, boost compliance, minimize errors, and generate insights quickly and accurately.

Here are a few practical ways AI is being used in the tax domain:

  • Automating routine processes: AI handles time-consuming tasks such as invoice matching, tax code validation, exemption certificate tracking, and return preparation, freeing tax professionals to focus on more strategic work.
  • Intelligent tax classification: AI tools accurately categorize goods and services into the right tax brackets, which enhances compliance and reduces costly mistakes.
  • Finding tax credits: Businesses can uncover overlooked opportunities like VAT reclaims or R&D credits through AI-powered data analysis.
  • Ensuring real-time compliance: AI continuously monitors transactions and flags non-compliance, helping companies stay up to date with evolving tax laws across regions.

Practical implementations are already happening. For instance, SAP Concur, in collaboration with AI companies like Bluedot, uses machine learning to automate VAT recovery on business travel expenses, a task that used to be manual and error-prone. Similarly, platforms like Vertex and Thomson Reuters OneSource are leveraging AI to apply tax rules accurately, organize tax data, categorize products and GL accounts, manage certificates, and maintain global tax compliance effortlessly.

Governments are also embracing AI to enhance public tax services and enforcement efforts:

  • AI-powered chatbots are helping taxpayers complete returns, get guidance, and understand forms in multiple languages.
  • Fraud detection tools powered by AI can analyze behavioral patterns and catch irregularities in filings that might signal tax evasion, something human auditors could miss.
  • Countries including Singapore, South Korea, France, and the UK are already using AI in areas like document processing, risk assessment, and taxpayer support.

However, integrating AI into tax operations does come with challenges:

  • Data security: Since tax data is highly sensitive, AI systems must meet strict privacy standards.
  • Bias and fairness: AI decisions are only as good as the data they’re trained on. Flawed or biased inputs can lead to inaccurate results.
  • Lack of transparency: Some AI systems work in a “black box” manner, making decisions without easily explainable logic, which raises accountability concerns.
  • Skills gap: As AI becomes a core part of tax operations, tax professionals need upskilling in technology and data to make the most of these tools.

Despite these challenges, the benefits of AI in tax are substantial. It’s not just about doing the same work faster. It’s about transforming how tax functions operate and contribute to business success. With AI, tax teams can:

  • Produce insights faster to support better decision-making
  • Monitor tax compliance globally in real time
  • Cut operational costs while improving accuracy
  • Align tax strategies with broader goals like ESG compliance and digital transformation

And this is just the start. As AI continues to evolve especially when paired with innovations like quantum computing and blockchain, we can expect even more advanced solutions that revolutionize tax management and governance.

For a deeper dive into this topic, I invite you to read my detailed paper:

“The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Taxation: The Role of AI and Key Use Cases”. This research paper explores the evolution of AI in taxation, practical examples, benefits, and key risks. It's free to read and download and is a great resource for anyone interested in the future of tax.

🔗 Click here to access the full paper

In conclusion, AI is no longer a "nice to have" in the world of tax—it’s becoming essential. For organizations and tax professionals ready to adapt, AI opens the door to smarter, faster, and more agile tax functions. The future of tax is not just digital, it’s intelligent.

entry.title: Need to learn skills essential steps for Concur Expense Professional Edition environment?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Getting Started with Concur Expense Professional Edition for Administrators learning journey.

Overview
This learning journey is designed to guide learners through the essential steps for successfully managing the Concur Expense Professional Edition environment as an administrator. It will help develop the skills necessary to ensure a smooth and compliant Expense management experience.

Learning objectives
By the end of this learning journey, learners will be able to:

  • Navigate and confidently manage various aspects of the Concur Expense Professional Edition environment as an administrator.
  • Oversee the entire expense report lifecycle — submission, review, approval, and audits to ensure adherence to company policies.
  • Provide practical support to end users.

Prerequisites
Essential:

  • Complete the Getting Started with Concur Expense for Customer Users learning journey before beginning this course.
Furthermore, learners should have
  • A basic understanding of their organization’s travel and expense policy.
  • Familiarity with general business processes related to expense management.
  • Access to a Concur Expense Professional Edition environment.
  • Basic knowledge of web-based administration tools.

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! We are here to support you. 

I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.
 
Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Data Access and Export for Concur Expense - Your Digital Tax Audit Assistant
entry.content:
This is a product update that you may not have received because this add-on product for Concur Expense was launched only in Germany in February 2025. However, it also affects all international Concur Expense clients who reimburse expenses in Germany.

Below you'll find high level information that may be relevant for you in the following cases:

  • your finance or payroll department in Germany requests structured and machine-readable data extracts for audit purposes
  • you have already created or you were requested to create "Expense Processor (Audit)" user profiles for audit purposes

This article is also available in our SAP Concur Community (Admin Group Forum) .

Simplify Tax Audits – With Minimal Effort and Maximum Control
You can use Data Access and Export service for Concur Expense to easily face internal and external audits of your Concur expense reports.

Few clicks are enough – and you provide the tax office or your internal audit with the exact data they want to see. No more and no less. This saves you time, reduces compliance risks, and maintains full control over your sensitive data.

The service makes it easy for you to comply with your duty to collaborate in tax audits.

Audit-relevant data at the push of a button
Whether the tax authority wants to access your billing data directly or requires a data export, every audit is tedious for your team – from compiling the relevant evidence to securing sensitive company information. Data Access and Export simplifies this process. Tax auditors and internal auditors get a quick overview of the data on the intuitive Web interface or they use a data extract in the standardized AIS format.

If required, they can navigate to the details. This saves valuable resources on both sides for a smooth and speedy audit.

Why is this relevant for Concur Expense?
Concur Expense is the source of truth for many tax-relevant calculations and payouts. This affects value added tax, income tax, but above all the employees’ wage tax.

For this reason, the tax authorities check this data during their external tax audits. Only with Data Access and Export can you quickly and easily restrict data access to the required scope and export large amounts of data in the shortest possible time.

Controlled Environment

  • Easily manage authorizations for data access
  • Quickly select requested time periods and companies
  • Limited access for tax audits

Efficient and convenient

  • Access via simple, intuitive Web interface
  • Immediate export in the established SAP audit format AIS
  • No manual effort for post-processing of exported data

Seamless integration

  • Can be enabled quickly as an add-on for Concur Expense Professional Edition. It is currently available for clients in Germany. Other countries will follow soon.
  • Deployed and managed by SAP as a web service on SAP Business Technology Platform (no own SAP BTP account required)

Want to learn more?
Your SAP Concur Customer Success Manager is here for you. For more information, visit the following pages (available only in German):

  • SAP Concur Webinar
  • Data Access and Export One Pager

entry.title: SAP Concur Fusion Exchange EMEA in London.
entry.content:
Reflections from Fusion Exchange EMEA 2025: SAP Integration in Action

On June 12th, I had the pleasure of attending Fusion Exchange EMEA in London, a one-day complimentary event designed to foster knowledge exchange among professionals managing travel, expense, and invoice processes. The event brought together SAP Concur experts, partners, and customers to explore the latest industry trends and value-adding solutions that help organizations maximize their SAP Concur investments.

Representing SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (ICS)

Together with my colleague Ryma Brahimi, I hosted the SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (ICS) booth. ICS is our area of expertise, and throughout the day we engaged with over 35 visitors—both prospective and existing customers. We fielded a wide range of questions, from setup and posting to fulfilling specific business requirements. It was a rewarding experience to connect directly with users and share insights into how ICS supports seamless financial integration.

A special thank you to Ryma—it was a joy to represent our product and team alongside you.

SAP Concur Keynote: A Vision for the Future

Although booth duties kept me busy, I made time to attend the SAP Concur keynote at 09:15. The session was truly inspiring. SAP Concur leaders unveiled their vision for the future of travel and expense management, highlighting innovations that are shaping the industry. Hearing real-world stories from customers was especially impactful. In my day-to-day work, I rarely get to see the “other side” of our solutions in action, and this keynote reminded me of the scale and significance of our work. It was a powerful moment of connection to the broader mission of SAP Concur.

Breakout Sessions: Innovation and AI in Action

Despite a packed schedule, I managed to attend two breakout sessions:

1. Managing Expenses: Innovations and Peer Use Cases

This session showcased tools like Concur Request, ExpenseIT on the Web, and integrations with Microsoft Teams and Outlook. The highlight for me—and likely many others—was the focus on AI at every step of the process. The presentation emphasized how AI is driving intelligent, front-loaded user experiences that optimize both compliance and usability. The pace of innovation in our industry is accelerating faster than I had imagined.

2. Revolutionizing Compliance Through Innovation and Technology

As someone with nearly 30 years in the financial software industry, compliance is a topic close to my heart. I’ve seen it evolve from an afterthought to a strategic priority. This session explored how AI can enhance spend compliance and usability through features like instant trip estimation, receipt capture, and automated hotel itemization. One slide noted a 93% reduction in approval time for rejected expense reports due to hotel itemization automation—a statistic that genuinely made me smile.

Stay Connected

If you're interested in learning more about SAP Financial Integration with Concur Solutions,  feel free to email sapconcurintegration@sap.com with “subscribe” in the subject line. You’ll receive an invitation to our Work Zone Workspaces (also known as SAP Jam pages), where you can explore resources and connect with our community.

Here you can find a link to Fusion EMEA 2025 Session Presentations  EMEA Fusion 2025 Session Presentations
A link to sign up for Fusion 2026 updates is at the bottom of the presentation page.

Damien Fleming
SAP Integration Specialist
Fusion Exchange EMEA 2025 Attendee

entry.title: Explore essential steps to configure and manage Concur Invoice Standard Edition for optimal invoice
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Getting Started with Concur Invoice Standard Edition for Administrators learning journey.

Overview
This learning journey provides essential steps for configuring and managing Concur Invoice Standard Edition, aiding both first-time setups and optimization for a smooth invoice management experience.

Learning objectives

Learners will be able to confidently manage the Concur Invoice Standard Edition environment and oversee the entire invoice lifecycle while providing practical support to end users.

Prerequisites

Essential:

  • A basic understanding of your organization’s procurement-to-pay process.
  • Familiarity with general business processes related to invoice management.
  • Access to a Concur Invoice Standard Edition environment.
  • Basic knowledge of web-based administration tools.

Optional: 

  • Prior experience with Concur solutions or reporting tools.

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! We are here to support you. 

I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards, Susann

entry.title: Things to consider during Concur Implementations
entry.content:
So how are you great people!! Today I thought of a scenario which we have successfully implemented for our clients which is not so difficult but if not designed properly can be a mess. We have all come across different scenarios while doing our Concur Implementations, from straightforward implementation to complex ones involving multiple integrations. In this blog I will like to explain one such scenario where we are bringing a new company into the existing Concur Instance. They will be roommates and will have their own individual policies and standards.

Introduction to the use case

So here's how it goes, there is a Company A which is using a Global Concur Instance for all its companies throughout the world. Now Company B which is basically a sister company having its own Concur instance decides to come into the existing Global Instance of Company A. Now the thing we have to remember here is, even though these are sister companies, they don't share any system with each other from HR system to ERP its all different. So this where the complexity lies in and where we need to put on our design cap and think before we start.

Steps to Follow:

Step 1: Custom Fields Audit:

Before we dive into the Requirement gathering phase, we have to do one audit of our existing instance which company A is using. We need to check how many custom fields are available, how many org fields are available, how many fields with the required data types are available and all that. Trust me this is the most difficult part of it all, there will be multiple places where we need to share the custom fields between the two instances.

Step 2: Primary Requirements:

Let start from the basics of the things that we need information about for this Company B. So your ORG structure is the most important stuff based on which you will get to know the countries in scope and how many levels of connected list you need to design. Since our Company A is using Org unit 1 to 3, we advised to have the org structure limited to the same 3 level format so that we can use Org unit 4 to 6 for country, Company and cost centers. One thing we need to communicate in the beginning to stake holders from Company B is we cannot use the authorized approver workflow as in feature Hierarchy, only one set of org units can be used for workflow. 

If you see below, the feature hierarchy can contain only one set of custom fields for authorized approver workflow, so it is important to communicate this at the start.

Please see the below screenshot where we have defined the connected list logic for the two companies using different set of custom fields.

We need to set up by creating the accounting hierarchy and create a new ledger if they are planning to use a different ERP system. 

Below you will see the accounting hierarchy set up for various companies based on their ledger preferences.

So once we get all the requirements locked, we will start as usual by creating groups, policy, forms and all the primary and secondary configurations as usual. The main thing to keep in mind during configuration of forms and fields is to make sure we are not disturbing the existing fields used for company A.

Important Considerations:

Another thing to keep in mind is during the Tax Configuration, this might be an issue if there a country in scope for Company B is already available in the system for Company A. The problem we might encounter is for example consider a country say Australia. For Company A, Airfare expense is configured to have a tax form with 3 tax rates, and for Company B same expense type has a standard tax rate for 10%. So what will happen in this case is even if try to exclude the company A while configuring the tax for Company B, since Tax is a country-based configuration, the tax form which is configured for Company A will be visible for Company B too even though it is not supposed to be.

Below you will see the screenshot where a single country can be configured with different reclaim codes based on their ERP .

 

So, the only solution to this is to create new expense types whenever there are countries we are bringing into the system which are already available in the instance.

Step 3: Integrations:

Once this is all done and all the other configurations completed, we need to work with the HR system for the company B for the integration. We need to provide all the required custom fields to the HR system's technical team so that mapping is completed and we get the daily import of 305 and 350 data. 

Here in the below screenshot, you can see how the Employee load with the 305 and 350 files are sent over to concur from two different HR systems, one is UKG and the other is Workday based on the respective HR systems the individual company uses.

Similar way the payment extract job needs to be setup for which we need to raise a ticket with Concur and provide all the group names for the company B which we have configured. While this is happening, we need to connect with the ERP team to map our SAE extract by providing the list of custom fields which are to be mapped in the ERP system.

Now we need to do multiple rounds of testing for company B, so that we make sure all the account codes, workflow, audit rules are working well and also need to test the posting into the ERP system. Also don't forget to do a round of regression testing for the Company A.

Conclusion:

By doing the above steps , we can bring in any new company into our existing instance even though they are supposed to follow a completely different set of configurations similar to Roommates, will share the same instance but they have different set of things for each other.

I hope I made the things clear from configuration point of view, and please let me know if you need to know any more details.

Until next time, Ciao!!

entry.title: SAP Integration with Concur Solutions: Default Configuration
entry.content:
SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (a.k.a. ICS, a.k.a. Native Integration) has been enhanced to simplify its setup. The enhancements are applicable for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2025, and for S/4HANA 2025. In this blog post, I will explain the changes.

The ICS team has been propagating a Best Practice configuration for a long time. This Best Practice configuration was already indicated in the different wizards, e.g., when setting up the export of the first cost object type, a 4-level cost object hierarchy is defaulted. We've changed the configuration approach slightly: When you complete the System Connection wizard for the first time, a default configuration is set up for the integration activities you've selected for your system. So, in an ideal case, you don't have to go into the different wizards to set up a configuration. Connection set up and ICS configuration can be finished within 2 min.

There is no defaulting for

  • Budget Integration (Travel Request, Expense Report Obligation)
    Note: This option is only visible only in a system where Public Sector functionality has been activated.
  • Invoice Integration (Vendor, Invoice)
    Note: This option is not offered for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

How does the default configuration look?

I won't go into the details of every single wizard. But I want to give you an idea how the configuration looks.

Applicable for all integration activities

For the set up, we distinguish between a productive system and a non-productive system. For productive systems, batch jobs are scheduled for replication of master data and import of transactional data. For non-productive systems, manual export/import will be configured.

Applicable for cost object replication

  • Cost object replication is set up for Export Without Restrictions. Phased Roll-Out isn't active.
  • A name analysis of the available Concur lists is done to determine which list might be intended to store the cost objects. Setting up a list in Concur named SAP Integration Hierarchy or CostObjects for storing the cost objects is recommended.
  • The cost object hierarchy is set up with 4 levels: Logical System, Company Code, Cost Object Type, and Cost Object ID.

Applicable for the import of transactional data

  • Filtering of documents is set up to happen on the employee fields.
  • An analysis is done on the Concur field names to determine the filtering. 
  • Journal Entry Type is set to ER (Manual Expense Travel).
  • Posting Date is set to Today and recalculation of the posting date is enabled.

Applicable for the import of expense reports

  • The Report Number will be picked for creating the reference key.
  • Clearing by XREF fields is defaulted.
  • Payment Notification is set to active.
  • An analysis is done on the Concur field names to determine the cost object mapping for your specific Concur system.
  • A journal entry per expense report is expected to be created.
  • Supplier line items are not supposed to be condensed.

With this default configuration, the ICS team tries to reduce the effort that is required for setting up a working configuration for setups which are close to the Best Practice set up for Concur.

entry.title: SAP Integration with Concur Solutions: Alternative Reference System and Reference Key
entry.content:
In this blog post, I describe the enhancements that have been made for handling reference keys within SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (a.k.a. ICS, a.k.a. Native Integration), enhancements applicable for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2025, and for SAP S/4HANA 2025. The enhancements impact the journal entry creation for expense reports and cash advances.

 

Changes affecting the Reference Key

When you look at a journal entry header, you see two fields containing the word Reference and are used to store a document identifier. The labeling differs slightly depending on the UI technology. In the Manage Journal Entry FIORI app, you have Document Reference ID and Original Reference Document.

 

In the transaction FB03, you have Reference and Reference Key.

For ICS, the leading field is the Original Reference Document/Reference Key. The Document Reference ID/Reference is a subset of the Reference Key. 

ICS constructs the Reference Key by picking an identifier of the Concur document, the revision ID of the Concur document, and the fixed value 1. Technically, the identifier of the Concur document and the revision ID are concatenated into a 10-character field (AWREF).  The fixed value is stored in a separate field. The fixed value is left out when constructing the content of the field Reference. For expense reports, ICS uses as identifier either the Report Number or Report Key. This can be configured within the Expense Report Import wizard, step Posting Settings. For Cash Advances, an artificial identifier is generated because Concur's Cash Advance ID is too long.

Starting with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508, we're offering the extension points BADI_CTE_FP_CB_AD_DETM_DOC_KEY and BADI_CTE_FP_CB_DETM_DOC_KEY. 

A similar option has been introduced for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025.

The extension points/BAdIs allow you to change the content of the AWREF field which is constructed from an identifier of the Concur document and the Concur document's revision ID (see above). This allows you, e.g., to remove spaces, replace letters with numbers etc.

Changes affecting the Reference System

To indicate the original system of an expense report or cash advance, ICS uses by default the System Key which is assigned to the Concur connection, e.g., 1,2,3 ...

Sometimes there is a need to use a specific reference or naming convention. That's why ICS offers a configuration option to define a value for the Reference System field. The configuration option is part of the System Connection wizard.

The system key is used as the default value for the field Reference System. When choosing the button Default Logical System, the current value of the Reference System field is replaced by the logical system. But you can also manually enter any 10-character string into the field.

Note: The Reference System field will become read-only after the first successful posting of an expense report or cash advance.

entry.title: SAP Integration with Concur Solutions: Improvements for Cost Object Replication
entry.content:
In this blog post, I describe the  enhancements that have been done for the cost object replication of SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (a.k.a. ICS, a.k.a. Native Integration), enhancements delivered with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508.

 

Improvements for Setting Up a Cost Object Hierarchy

To support hybrid scenarios, setting up cost object hierarchies became more flexible.

 

Standard List Levels

Let's first look at the pre-delivered levels available for defining a hierarchy for the cost object replication. A new standard level has been made available: Controlling Area. 

In total, ICS supports 6 list levels in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud out-of-the-box.

  • Logical System: This list level identifies the FI entity where the cost object comes from. As many customers are connecting several FI entities to the same Concur entity, the level is required to separate the cost objects of the different FI entities.
  • Company Code: The company code to which the cost object belongs
  • Cost Object ID: The ID of a cost object 
  • Cost Object Type: Cost objects of different types are oftentimes stored in the same list. The Cost Object Type level defines what type of ID is expected to be found on the Cost Object ID level.
  • Country/Region: This level determines to which country respectively region a cost object belongs
  • Controlling Area: This levels identifies the controlling area to which the cost object belongs. 

The recommended set up is a 4-level list consisting of Logical System, Company Code, Cost Object Type, and Cost Object ID levels. This list set up combines technical requirements, i.e., the need to separate cost objects from different systems, and usability requirements. Combined with a set up where at least the values Logical System and Company Code are defaulted from an employee's master data for cost allocation on the expense report, the employee only needs to enter a bare minimum of data, i.e., the employee only needs to pick a cost object type and a cost object. In many set ups, the employee's home cost center is defaulted for cost allocation. If the employee is supposed to fully book a trip on the home cost center, no input at all is required from the employee for specifying the cost allocation.

Note: The Concur UIs for the non-admin users are usually configured to hide the level Logical System. Companies that don't allow intercompany posting scenarios can also hide the level Company Code from the non-admin users.

 

Customer-Specific List Levels

Starting with the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, it is  possible to create customer-specific list levels in the Cost Object Export wizards, step Cost Object Hierarchy by pressing the button Manage Additional Fields. 

Press the + button to add a new level. You can enter a field name which allows you to identify the level when setting up a cost object hierarchy. The values from the columns Concur Item Code and Concur Item Name will be displayed in Concur when you need to pick a value for your customer-specific hierarchy level. 

 

Note: Unlike for S/4HANA on-Premise respectively S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, it is not possible to implement a BAdI/Extension Point to create values for the customer-specific levels in dependence of a given cost object, e.g., to define for cost center 4711 that the customer-specific level should get the code ABCD and to define for cost center 4712 that the customer-specific level should get the code XYZ.

Use the customer-specific level when setting up your cost object hierarchy:

Those are the enhancements that bring more flexibility to the set up of cost object hierarchies.

 

Extension Point

The extension point BADI_CTE_CB_COST_OBJECT was introduced to influence the cost object replication in a programmatic way. The extension point allows you to cover, among others, the following use cases:

  • Change the name of a cost object to meet language requirements when the current cost object name is different than the Concur default language.
  • Use this extension point to exclude individual objects instead of using the Single Objects Table in the Phased Rollout option or in the Exclude from Export option for the respective cost object export.

Specifically, you can

  • Change the name of a cost object in the Concur list
  • Exclude a cost object from the export so it is no longer considered
  • Delete a cost object that was previously exported to the Concur system

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 6: SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur
entry.content:
This sixth post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur. For SAP Customer Experience, look at the new AI agents and the capability to build custom agents, plus AI innovations for marketeers in SAP Emarsys, and Joule and AI order summaries in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.  SAP Concur takes travel planning to the next level with the whole new travel experience, complemented by the new Joule Booking Agent enabling users to use natural language to book a trip.

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 

SAP Customer Experience

The user experience highlights I have picked are all AI-related:

  • AI Agents.
  • SAP Emarsys UX innovations.
  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 UX innovations.

This news article summarizes what’s new overall for SAP Customer Experience, beyond UX-related innovations:

  • Connected for Growth: What’s New with SAP Customer Experience in Q2 2025.

AI Agents

As I explained in part 1 of this series, AI agents work in the background to give a greatly enhanced user experience. A number of powerful AI agents are available for SAP Customer Experience, via the package Joule Premium for Customer Experience. This blog post and video give a nice overview of three of them in action:

  • AI Agents in Action.
  • Video: See How AI Agents Streamline Customer Service (3:11 min.)

The latest UX innovations are:

  • Shopping Agent for the Shopping Assistant.
  • Digital Service Agent (via Early Adopter Care program).
  • Ability to create custom agents in the CX AI Toolkit.

AI Shopping Agent for the SAP Commerce Cloud Shopping Assistant

The shopping agent helps customers when visiting an online shop: they can simply use natural language to state what they are looking for, and the shopping agent will respond with suitable suggestions. Figure 1 shows an example, where the user starts out by stating that they are looking for shoes to wear for two mile long walks while wearing a suit. Two shoes are suggested, and the user asks which one is comfortable right away, since he doesn’t want a long break in period. The agent recommends one model, and the customer then asks for a recommendation for a belt to match, which the agent promptly gives him.

Figure 1: Shopping Agent for the Shopping Assistant from SAP Commerce Cloud. Alt Text: three screenshots of a tall and narrow screen showing a chat, one for each of the interactions explained in the main text. Each response shows one or two images: in the first case two shoes, then one shoe and then one men’s belt.

Find out more here, and watch the video embedded there to see it in action:

  • SAP Discovery Center: Shopping Agent

Digital Service Agent

The new digital service agent helps to provide your customers with a great user experience, similar to how the shopping agent is aimed primarily at your customers. It enables customers to ask questions with natural language and provides answers based on your company’s business knowledge residing in the SAP system. Hence, it is able to resolve common inquiries and issues, giving customers a good experience. Furthermore, by freeing up you sales and service team to focus on more complex inquiries, your customers will also receive a better service and hence better experience.

The digital serice agent is currently only available for select customers via the Early Adopter Care program. Figure 2 in the next section shows how these customers can select it in the AI Agent Builder.

Find out more here:

  • SAP Discovery Center: Digital Service Agent.

Create Custom Agents with CX AI Toolkit

You can now create your own custom agents with the CX AI toolkit. Figure 2 shows the start screen for the AI Agent Builder, where you can select “Custom Tool” to start the wizard which takes you through the steps to create a custom agent.

Figure 2: The AI Agent Builder in the CX AI Tookit for creating custom AI agents or using SAP templates to create AI agents. Alt Text: A screenshot with “Let’s Create AI Agents” in large text in the middle below an illustration, below in much smaller text “Start by selecting an Agent Template”. Below that, two rows of three cards representing Agent Templates are shown: Custom Tool, Knowledge Agent, Classification Agent, Digital Service Agent, Q/A Agent, and Shopping Assistant Agent.

Find out more here:

  • Documentation: Create a Custom AI Agent.

Further Information on AI Agents for SAP Customer Experience

For a deeper understanding of the power of these AI agents, have a look at this longer video:

  • Video: SAP CX AI Toolkit: AI Insights Agents for SAP C4C & Shopping Assistant | Product Inspiration Series (32:21 min.)

SAP Emarsys

AI-Assisted Report Builder using Natural Language

You can now easily create a report using natural language to describe what you are interested in. Figure 3 shows an example of the entry screen. At the bottom you see hints on what kind of queries you can enter.

Figure 3: AI-assisted report builder in SAP Emarsys. Alt Text: A screenshot with “Unlock the Power of Data with the AI-assisted Report Builder” in the middle. At the top a text entry field containing the query “What are the Sent, Delivered, Bounced, Opened, Clicked, Purchased, Unsubscribed, Complained for my Email campaigns in the past month?”, to the right an AI button “Generate Report”. At the bottom of the screen two example queries are listed.

Once you have created the report, you can easily adjust it using a set of convenient filters, such as the date range as well as the list of campaigns and metrics. Watch this video to see it in action:

  • Video: AI-assisted Report Builder (46 seconds).

AI-assisted Product Finder using Natural Language (Pilot)

Pilot customers can now try out the new AI-assisted product finder, which allows users to search for product to add to marketing campaigns using natural language. Figure 4 shows an example of how to enter your search text, see more here:

  • Video: AI-assisted Product Finder (38 seconds).

Figure 4: AI-assisted product finder available to SAP Emarsys pilot customers. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a screen with a left half containing the Product Finder, with a search field containing “Most popular shoes in the last 6 month”, above an empty space with the text “Welcome to Product Finder!” in the middle. The right half shows an image of someone dancing in the sun and an image of a dress, along with some describing text.

Read more about latest SAP Emarsys innovations here:

  • SAP Emarsys Q2 2025 Product Release.
  • SAP Emarsys introduces new generative AI capabilities in June Product Release

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Joule in SAP Sales Cloud

Joule is now available in SAP Sale Cloud Verion 2, helping users get quick insights, for example about an account. As you can see in Figure 5, these insights can be charts as well as text based.

Figure 5: Joule for SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot of Joule showing Customer Account Overview, with the text “Show Key Metrics” entered as chat, below which a card with a vertical stacked bar chart shows credit limit usage (remaining amount and exposure amount), below that a card showing Key Metrics (Activity) and part of a donut chart for Tasks, Phone Calls, Appointments, Visits etc.

Have a deeper look here:

  • Video: Intelligent Selling with Joule in SAP Sales Cloud & SAP S/4HANA Cloud | Product Inspiration Series (16:04 min.)

Sales Order Summary

The Sales Order Summary uses generative AI to summarize key information about the sales order, as well as including information about some changes, for example how the price compares to the original price. Figure 6 shows an example, with the insights shown on the left of the screen.

Figure 6: Sales Order Summary in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a sales order, with the left third showing an overview with AI-generated insights such as “13 days past requested date”, “Overall discount is EUR 808.55”. On the right, the Order Summary tab is shown, with account name, net and gross value, pricing stats, above “Products in Cart (2)” showing a list of two products, followed by the top part of a list of pricing steps.

Learn more here:

  • Documentation: Sales Order Summary.

 

SAP Concur

The new Concur Travel experience makes it much easier to book travel involving multiple bookings, such as a flight plus hotel plus rental car. And if you just need to book one item, you can do that very easily now with the new Booking Agent powered by Joule.

New Concur Travel Experience

When travelling for a few days, one often needs to book more than one item. A typical combination is booking a flight, a hotel and a rental car. Up until now, you have had to book each item separately and take care that the dates and time match. Now, with the new Concur Travel experience, planning and booking is much easier: you can enter the start and end dates for your flight, and the new feature Match Flight Booking is applied to the hotel and car, so that dates and time match automatically.

Figures 7 to 11 show what this looks like: Figure 7 shows the start screen, where you select which items you want to include (flight, hotel, car, train). Figure 8 shows the flight view, where flight dates have been entered. Figure 9 shows the hotel search, with the default selection “Based on flight selection”, and similarly Figure 10 shows the rental car search, with pick-up and return times calculated based on the flight schedule. Figure 11 shows the finalize screen, in this case showing that the flight and hotel has been selected but the rental car is still open.

Figure 7: New Concur Travel experience start screen. Alt Text: A screenshot of a pop-over with a large image of a magnifying glass on a globe, above the text “Start Planning”. Below that four check boxes in a row: Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train, at the bottom “Continue” and “Cancel” buttons.

Figure 8: New Concur Travel experience screen with flight details. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a trip planning for a Trip to Las Vegas. The left third of the screen shows a list with items Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, with Flight selected. Below the list buttons “Add to trip” and “Search”. On the right a selector for round-trip (selected), one-way or multi-city, with fields for from / to locations and a date field for the stard and end date. To the right a button “Time preferences” and a drop-down for selecting “Cabin”.

Figure 9: New Concur Travel experience screen with hotel details. Alt Text: As for Figure 8, but with Hotel selected, and on the right Hotel Search displayed, with the fields for “Hotel, location, or name” and “Dates” filled with the text “Based on flight selection”.

 Figure 10: New Concur Travel experience screen with rental car details. Alt Text: As for Figure 9, but with Rental Car selected, and on the right Rental Car Search displayed, with the fields for “Pickup” and “Dates” filled with the text “Based on flight selection” and the field “Drop-off” filled with “Same as pickup”. Pickup Time and Drop-off Time fields have 10:00 AM entered.

Figure 11: New Concur Travel experience finalize screen. Alt Text: Screenshot showing “Trip to Las Vegas” on the left two-thirds, with a card summarizing the flight with United Airlines from San Antonio, TX (SAT) – Las Vegas, NV (LAS) and a card summarizing the hotel Courtyard by Marriott Las Vegas. The right third shows the Estimated Total Cost $2497.85 above a list with the cost of each item (flight, hotel, rental car), and buttons for “Finalize Trip” and “Cancel Trip”, and options to book anything else (Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train).

As you can see in Figure 11, another advantage of the new experience is that you get budget transparency at the trip level. Also, you have flexibility to book parts of the travel now and other parts later.

Technically it supports deep linking, which means that you can send a trip-level link to colleagues which includes all the trip parts, making it easy to coordinate trip planning when travelling with others.

To find out more, have a look at the

  • Documentation: Trip Planning in New Concur Travel.

Booking Agent in Concur Travel

The new Booking Agent lets you use natural language to book business travel which is compliant with company policy and budget constraints as well as taking into account your personal travel preferences.

Figure 12 shows an example where the user has simply stated “I want to book a flight from San Francisco to London on Sept 9th and back on Sept 13th”. The answer shown takes into account the user’s frequent traveler memberships, flight availability and company policies.

Figure 12: New Concur Travel Booking Agent in Joule. Alt Text: A screenshot of Concur Travel with Joule opened on the right, the content is explained in the main text, with the possible flights listed alongside a thumbnail image representing the airline “jetBlue”.

Watch it in action and find out more:

  • Video: Concur Travel – Booking Agent demo (2:33 min.)
  • SAP Discovery Center: Booking Agent.

 

Continue Reading - UX Innovations in UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile

I hope you enjoyed this sixth part, covering SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur, with great new AI-powered user experiences helping users work more efficiently and effectively.

Here is the link to the final part seven, covering latest innovations in UI design and technology for web and mobile:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

entry.title: Quality Gates in SAP Activate for SAP Concur Road Map
entry.content:
Our SAP Activate road maps are designed to grow alongside your journey. Through the SAP Activate team’s blog, you can see how they continuously evolve—never static, always adapting. This ongoing refinement ensures you receive the right guidance, whether you’re implementing a single SAP solution or an entire suite of products.

Building on this commitment, our SAP Activate for SAP Concur road map now includes a dedicated Quality Gate Checklist tailored specifically for SAP Concur projects. Accessible directly in the Road Map Viewer and in SAP Cloud ALM, it brings greater structure and clarity to your implementation process.

This checklist is essential for ensuring project success. It provides a structured framework to evaluate progress at key milestones. It enables teams to verify that critical deliverables meet predefined standards before advancing to the next phase, helping to mitigate potential risks. Through its structured approach, the checklist promotes transparency and accountability while instilling confidence that the project remains aligned with business objectives.

In this way, it serves as both a safeguard and a guide, helping organizations deliver implementations more efficiently, consistently, and with higher-quality outcomes. As illustrated below, this is reflected in action in the Road Map Viewer and SAP Cloud ALM.

At the end of each phase, you will find the task for Quality Gate.

In SAP Cloud ALM, once we have created a project with the SAP Concur road map, the quality gates will be available in the Quality Gates App. See sequence below:

Step (1)

Step (2): Open the phase you want to check the Quality Gates:

Step (3): Once it is opened, scroll to check the checklist item:

We have a taxonomy to qualitatively set the status of the quality gate item in the road map viewer and in SAP Cloud ALM.

A taxonomy is available to qualitatively indicate the status of each Quality Gate item within the Road Map Viewer and SAP Cloud ALM.

Quality Gates give you a solid qualitative view of your project—but the numbers can tell the full story.

Curious how to turn those insights into a measurable, quantitative perspective?

Drop your thoughts in the comments, and don’t miss the next post! 😉

entry.title: Future-proof your SAP support journey with Support Accreditation
entry.content:
Discover what’s new in the Support Accreditation 2025 release

In today’s fast-paced business environment, speed and resilience are critical. Organizations that fully leverage their SAP solutions are better positioned to overcome challenges swiftly, avoid disruptions, and generate long-term value. That’s where Support Accreditation comes in — your guided path to mastering SAP’s intelligent support capabilities.

Support Accreditation is a free, self-enabled learning journey that empowers SAP customers, partners, and employees with the requisite knowledge of SAP’s support offerings and tools. The latest six-unit accreditation is designed to equip all SAP users when engaging with support from SAP.

Support Accreditation learning journey on learning.sap.com

 

Why Support Accreditation Matters

Support Accreditation offers a quick, easy, and impactful way to upskill through a structured learning journey - empowering you and your teams to stay ahead. Here’s how it delivers impact:

  • Maximize Your SAP Investment: Learn how to unlock the full value of your SAP solutions by leveraging support resources for faster, more effective problem-solving.
  • Resolve Issues Proactively: Prevent disruptions and avoid escalations using self-service tools and real-time support capabilities.
  • Stay Ahead with Intelligent Support: Get familiar with SAP’s AI-driven and predictive support technologies to stay on the cutting edge.
  • Streamline Support Interactions: Reduce back-and-forth by understanding how to navigate SAP’s support channels and escalate efficiently.
  • Earn a Recognized Accreditation: Validate your knowledge with an official digital badge that demonstrates your expertise.
  • Follow Scenario-Based Learning Paths: Access tailored guidance for SAP Concur, Procurement, and explore key tools like SAP Cloud ALM.

Learning journey is easy to consume with relevant screenshots and walkthrough videos

Interactive yet easy quizzes for quick knowledge checks

 

What’s New in the Latest 2025 Release

The 2025 update to Support Accreditation introduces powerful new content designed to help you get even more from your SAP support tools and services. With the latest release, we have streamlined and updated the content to include the latest most relevant information while also introducing new units that can enhance your support services utilization and experience. Here's what’s new:

Customer Insights Dashboard: Your Command Center for the health of your SAP system

Monitor your SAP landscape with a single, interactive dashboard. View case statuses, usage statistics, service consumption, and more through tailored reports — all in one place. The Customer Insights Dashboard will help you align support insights with business goals to improve decision-making and drive greater value.

Intelligent Search: Smarter Answers, Faster

No more wading through endless documents. The new AI-powered search in SAP for Me understands the intent behind your questions, not just the keywords. It connects you instantly to the most relevant documentation, KBAs, community posts, or embedded help content. With semantic understanding and vector-based retrieval, this is your shortcut to faster problem-solving and more confident self-service.

Support Interaction Survey: Your Voice, Our Action

Your feedback now directly shapes the future of SAP support. The Support Interaction Survey prompts you to share your experience after closing a case, whether positive or challenging. Low-effort scores trigger proactive follow-ups from our support managers, while high ratings help us celebrate and recognize excellence across our teams. Every response ensures your voice is heard and drives tangible improvements in the support you receive.

Strengthening Collaboration with SAP Partners: A Unified Experience

Collaboration just got more seamless with dedicated partner engagement section. Partner engagement and management in SAP for Me helps customers and partners work hand-in-hand with SAP support. With partner-specific dashboards, role-based access and analytics tools, this update empowers partners to deliver faster, more effective support on your behalf. The result? Greater visibility, smoother collaboration, and a stronger ecosystem working together for your success.

 

Get Started Today

With Support Accreditation, you’re not just learning, you’re future proofing your SAP journey. Whether you’re new to SAP or a seasoned professional, this is your opportunity to stay prepared, stay informed, and stay ahead.

Get accredited today at Support Accreditation on learning.sap.com

Check out our info-sheet for a quick overview on Support Accreditation.

Badge of completion issued as record of achievement
